commit_message:
Fix Sahara CI links

* fix wrong URL to Jenkins
* add link to Sahara Zuul status page
* add link to Sahara CI wiki page

The install and configuration guide for object storage has
proxy-server.conf contents with /home/swift/keystone-signing as

commit_message:
Corrects proxy server conf in swift install guide

The install and configuration guide for object storage has
proxy-server.conf contents with /home/swift/keystone-signing as
signing directory. Without the directory being available swift proxy
service is unable to start. Signing directory is a temporary cache
directory which defaults to /tmp. Hence removing this entry makes
/tmp as default signing directory. This patch removes signing_dir
option to make swift use /tmp as signing directory implicitly.

Change-Id: I8b9b70b30af2767f48705acb14329833179b96fc
Closes-Bug: #1329798
(cherry picked from commit abed3e59e159136b39a498a013983d0cf9efded9)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/91/101091/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Notify systemd when starting Neutron server

systemd is notified only when Neutron is started with multiple api
workers. This patch adds systemd.notify_once() call when starting
Neutron server with api_workers=0

Closes-Bug: #1330532

Conflicts:
	neutron/wsgi.py

Change-Id: I95581dc5dffde6168c68d9f04cf8bdfcdb773ba8
(cherry picked from commit 09856a0cf63052045b3d9f4c8d2a5aa920c7c935)

commit_message:
Sync service and systemd modules from oslo-incubator

This patch make systemd know when neutron-service was started. This is
needed in HA environment, previously systemd returned success even
before neutron-server was able to handle requests.

Current oslo-incubator commit on HEAD:
b7ad6ddab8b1d61bf4f52ccaa461a9d68809747b

Implements: blueprint service-readiness
Change-Id: Ic9e4abd11b614a896fbd7454b9a604a69a248d0f
(cherry picked from commit 149679b2dc2e202b37580a3210f3a25628c4339b)

added_lines: "POT-Creation-Date: 2014-06-19 06:03+0000\n"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:10(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:160(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:20(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:22(para) msgid "The most important step is the pre-upgrade testing. If you are upgrading immediately after release of a new version, undiscovered bugs might hinder your progress. Some deployers prefer to wait until the first point release is announced. However, if you have a significant deployment, you might follow the development and testing of the release to ensure that bugs for your use cases are fixed.upgradingpre-upgrade testing"msgid "Even if you have what seems to be a near-identical architecture as the one described in this guide, each OpenStack cloud is different. As a result, you must still test upgrades between versions in your environment. For this, you need an approximate clone of your environment."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:39(para) msgid "However, that is not to say that it needs to be the same size or use identical hardware as the production environment—few of us have that luxury. It is important to consider the hardware and scale of the cloud that you are upgrading, but these tips can help you avoid that incredible cost:upgradingcontrolling cost of"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:51(term)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:54(para) msgid "The simplest place to start testing the next version of OpenStack is by setting up a new environment inside your own cloud. This might seem odd—especially the double virtualization used in running compute nodes—but it's a sure way to very quickly test your configuration."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:63(term)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:66(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:80(term)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:83(para) msgid "If you use an external storage plug-in or shared file system with your cloud, in many cases, you can test whether it works by creating a second share or endpoint. This action enables you to test the system before entrusting the new version onto your storage."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:92(term)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:95(para) msgid "Even at smaller-scale testing, look for excess network packets to determine whether something is going horribly wrong in inter-component communication."msgid "To set up the test environment, you can use one of several methods:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:109(para) msgid "Do a full manual install by using the OpenStack Installation Guide for your platform. Review the final configuration files and installed packages." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:116(para) msgid "Create a clone of your automated configuration infrastructure with changed package repository URLs." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:118(para) msgid "Alter the configuration until it works."msgid "Either approach is valid. Use the approach that matches your experience."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:123(para) msgid "An upgrade pre-testing system is excellent for getting the configuration to work; however, it is important to note that the historical use of the system and differences in user interaction can affect the success of upgrades, too. We've seen experiences where database migrations encountered a bug (later fixed!) because of slight table differences between fresh Grizzly installs and those that migrated from Folsom to Grizzly." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:131(para) msgid "Artificial scale testing can go only so far. After your cloud is upgraded, you must pay careful attention to the performance aspects of your cloud." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:137(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:139(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:162(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:166(para) msgid "Perform some \"cleaning\" of the environment prior to starting the upgrade process to ensure a consistent state. For example, instances not fully purged from the system after deletion might cause indeterminate behavior."msgid "Read the release notes and documentation."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:177(para) msgid "Find incompatibilities between your versions." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:181(para) msgid "Develop an upgrade procedure and assess it thoroughly by using a test environment similar to your production environment." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:187(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:192(para) msgid "You can perform an upgrade with operational instances, but this strategy can be dangerous. You might consider using live migration to temporarily relocate instances to other compute nodes while performing upgrades. However, you must ensure database consistency throughout the process; otherwise your environment might become unstable. Also, don't forget to provide sufficient notice to your users, including giving them plenty of time to perform their own backups."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:201(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:206(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:211(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:215(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:220(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:224(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:228(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:233(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:238(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:243(para) msgid "Upgrade the packages by using your distribution's package manager."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:248(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:253(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:259(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:264(para) msgid "For this section, we assume that you are starting with the architecture provided in the OpenStack OpenStack Installation Guide and upgrading to the same architecture for Havana. All nodes should run Ubuntu 12.04 LTS. This section primarily addresses upgrading core OpenStack services, such as the Identity Service (keystone), Image Service (glance), Compute (nova) including networking, Block Storage (cinder), and the dashboard.upgradingGrizzly to Havana (Ubuntu)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:279(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:666(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1047(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1441(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:281(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:668(para) msgid "The upgrade process interrupts management of your environment, including the dashboard. If you properly prepare for this upgrade, tenant instances continue to operate normally."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:288(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:675(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1056(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1450(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:290(para) Particularly, if you are running Django 1.5 or later, you must ensure that /etc/openstack-dashboard/local_settings contains a correctly configured key that contains a list of host names recognized by the dashboard."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:452(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:860(para) msgid "If users access your dashboard by using http://dashboard.example.com, define , as follows:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:458(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:866(para) msgid "If users access your dashboard on the local system, define , as follows:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:463(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:871(para) msgid "If users access your dashboard by using an IP address in addition to a host name, define , as follows:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:471(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:879(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:473(para) msgid "Upgrade packages on the controller node to Havana, as follows:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:480(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1145(para) msgid "Depending on your specific configuration, performing a dist-upgrade might restart services supplemental to your OpenStack environment. For example, if you use Open-iSCSI for Block Storage volumes and the upgrade includes a new open-scsi package, the package manager restarts Open-iSCSI services, which might cause the volumes for your users to be disconnected."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:489(para) msgid "The package manager prompts you to update various configuration files. Reject these changes. The package manager appends .dpkg-dist to the newer versions of existing configuration files. You should consider adopting conventions associated with the newer configuration files and merging them with your existing configuration files after completing the upgrade process."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:499(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:908(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:502(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:911(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:509(term) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:918(term)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:520(term) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:929(term)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:532(term) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:941(term)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:552(term) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:961(term)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:564(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:973(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:569(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:978(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:572(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:981(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:578(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:624(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:986(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:584(para) msgid "Due to a packaging issue, this command might fail with the following error:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:596(para) msgid "Fix this issue by running this command:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:601(para) msgid "The packaging system prompts you to update the /etc/nova/api-paste.ini file. As with the controller upgrade, we recommend that you reject these changes and review the .dpkg-dist file after the upgrade process completes."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:607(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:615(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1004(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:618(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1007(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:629(para) msgid "The packaging system prompts you to update the /etc/cinder/api-paste.ini file. Like the controller upgrade, reject these changes and review the .dpkg-dist file after the the upgrade process completes."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:637(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:645(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:650(para) msgid "For this section, we assume that you are starting with the architecture provided in the OpenStack OpenStack Installation Guide and upgrading to the same architecture for Havana. All nodes should run Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6.4 or compatible derivatives. Newer minor releases should also work. This section primarily addresses upgrading core OpenStack services, such as the Identity Service (keystone), Image Service (glance), Compute (nova) including networking, Block Storage (cinder), and the dashboard.upgradingGrizzly to Havana (Red Hat)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:687(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:701(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:722(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:766(para) msgid "If currently present, remove the following key from the [filter:authtoken] section in the /etc/glance/glance-api-paste.ini and /etc/glance/glance-registry-paste.ini files:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:785(para) msgid "Remove defunct database configuration from the /etc/nova/nova.conf file:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:804(para) msgid "On all compute nodes, increase the DHCP lease time (measured in seconds) in the /etc/nova/nova.conf file to enable currently active instances to continue leasing their IP addresses during the upgrade process, as follows:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:821(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:827(para)msgid "Remove defunct database configuration from the /etc/cinder/cinder.conf file:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:851(para) msgid "The dashboard installation procedure and configuration file changed substantially between Grizzly and Havana. Particularly, if you are running Django 1.5 or later, you must ensure that the /etc/openstack-dashboard/local_settings file contains a correctly configured key that contains a list of host names recognized by the dashboard." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:881(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:886(para) msgid "Some services might terminate with an error during the package upgrade process. If this error might cause a problem with your environment, consider stopping all services before upgrading them to Havana."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:892(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:898(para) msgid "The package manager appends .rpmnew to the end of newer versions of existing configuration files. You should consider adopting conventions associated with the newer configuration files and merging them with your existing configuration files after completing the upgrade process."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:991(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:996(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1012(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1018(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1023(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1029(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1032(para) msgid "For this section, we assume that you are starting with the architecture provided in the OpenStack Installation Guide and upgrading to the same architecture for Icehouse. All nodes should run Ubuntu 12.04 LTS with Linux kernel 3.11 and the latest Havana packages installed and operational. This section primarily addresses upgrading core OpenStack services such as Identity (keystone), Image Service (glance), Compute (nova), Networking (neutron), Block Storage (cinder), and the dashboard. The Networking upgrade includes conversion from the Open vSwitch (OVS) plug-in to the Modular Layer 2 (M2) plug-in. This section does not cover the upgrade process from Ubuntu 12.04 LTS to Ubuntu 14.04 LTS."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1048(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1442(para) msgid "The upgrade process interrupts management of your environment, including the dashboard. If you properly prepare for this upgrade, tenant instances continue to operate normally. However, instances might experience intermittent network interruptions while the Networking service rebuilds virtual networking infrastructure."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1057(para) msgid "Always review the Icehouse Release Notes before you upgrade to learn about newly available features that you might want to enable and deprecated features that you should disable."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1065(para) msgid "Save the configuration files on all nodes:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1079(para) msgid "Although not necessary, you should consider updating your MySQL server configuration as described in the MySQL controller setup section of the OpenStack Installation Guide." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1090(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1485(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1095(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1101(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1500(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1104(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1503(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1105(para) msgid "Icehouse disables file injection by default per the Icehouse Release Notes."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1109(para) msgid "If you plan to deploy Icehouse in stages, you must disable file injection on all compute nodes that remain on Havana."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1112(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1511(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1120(para) msgid "Convert from the OVS plug-in to the ML2 plug-in:"msgid "You must convert the configuration for your environment contained in the /etc/neutron/neutron.conf and /etc/neutron/plugins/openvswitch/ovs_neutron_plugin.ini files from OVS to ML2. For example, the OpenStack Installation Guide covers ML2 plug-in configuration using GRE tunnels."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1133(para) msgid "Keep the OVS plug-in packages and configuration files until you verify the upgrade."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1139(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1537(title) msgid "Upgrade the Controller Node"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1140(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1538(para) msgid "Upgrade packages on the controller node to Icehouse, as follows:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1153(para) msgid "The package manager prompts you to update various configuration files. Reject these changes. The package manager appends .dpkg-dist to the newer versions of existing configuration files. You should consider adopting conventions associated with the newer configuration files and merging them with your existing configuration files after completing the upgrade process. You can find newer versions of existing configuration files with the following command:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1165(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1553(title) msgid "Upgrade Each Service"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1166(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1554(para) msgid "The upgrade procedure for each service typically requires that you stop the service, run the database synchronization command to update the associated database, and start the service to apply the new configuration. ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1423(title) msgid "How to Perform an Upgrade from Havana to Icehouse—Red Hat Enterprise Linux and Derivatives"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1426(para) msgid "For this section, we assume that you are starting with the architecture provided in the OpenStack OpenStack Installation Guide and upgrading to the same architecture for Icehouse. All nodes should run Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6.5 or compatible derivatives such as CentOS and Scientific Linux with the latest Havana packages installed and operational. This section primarily addresses upgrading core OpenStack services such as Identity (keystone), Image Service (glance), Compute (nova), Networking (neutron), Block Storage (cinder), and the dashboard. The Networking upgrade procedure includes conversion from the Open vSwitch (OVS) plug-in to the Modular Layer 2 (ML2) plug-in."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1451(para) msgid "Always review the release notes before performing an upgrade to learn about newly available features that you might want to enable and deprecated features that you should disable."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1474(para) msgid "You must update your MySQL server configuration and restart the service as described in the MySQL controller setup section of the OpenStack Installation Guide."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1491(para) msgid "Disable any automatic package updates."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1494(para) msgid "Consider checking for newer versions of the Icehouse repository."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1504(para) msgid "Icehouse disables file injection by default per the release notes."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1508(para) msgid "If you plan to deploy Icehouse in stages, you must disable file injection on all compute nodes that will remain on Havana."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1519(para) msgid "Convert from OVS to ML2 plug-in:"msgid "You must convert the configuration for your environment contained in the /etc/neutron/neutron.conf and /etc/neutron/plugins/openvswitch/ovs_neutron_plugin.ini files from OVS to ML2. For example, the OpenStack Installation Guide covers ML2 plug-in configuration using GRE tunnels."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1531(para) msgid "We recommend keeping the OVS plug-in packages and configuration files until you verify the upgrade."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1542(para) msgid "The package manager appends .rpmnew to the end of newer versions of existing configuration files. You should consider adopting conventions associated with the newer configuration files and merging them with your existing configuration files after completing the upgrade process. You can find newer versions of existing configuration files with the following command:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1581(para) msgid "Before you upgrade the Image Service database, convert the character set for each table to UTF-8." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1583(para) msgid "Use the MySQL client to run the following commands:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1596(para) msgid "Your environment might contain different or additional tables that you must convert to UTF-8 by using similar commands." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1613(para) msgid "Add Qpid message broker keys to the [DEFAULT] section." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1633(para) msgid "Change the key from nova.openstack.common.rpc.impl_qpid to qpid." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1661(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1753(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1784(para) msgid "Install the ML2 plug-in package:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1669(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1764(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1795(para) msgid "Change the /etc/neutron/plugin.ini symbolic link to reference /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1730(para) msgid "Edit the /etc/openstack-dashboard/local_settings file:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1819(title) msgid "Cleaning Up and Final Configuration File Updates" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1821(para) msgid "On all distributions, you must perform some final tasks to complete the upgrade process.upgradingfinal steps" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1827(para) msgid "Decrease DHCP timeouts by modifying /etc/nova/nova.conf on the compute nodes back to the original value for your environment." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1831(para) msgid "Update all .ini files to match passwords and pipelines as required for Havana in your environment." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1835(para) msgid "After a migration, your users see different results from and unless you match policies for access to private images. To do so, edit the /etc/glance/policy.json and /etc/nova/policy.json files to contain \"context_is_admin\": \"role:admin\", which limits access to private images for projects." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1844(para) msgid "Thoroughly test the environment. Then, let your users know that their cloud is running normally again." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1849(title) msgid "Rolling Back a Failed Upgrade" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1851(para) msgid "Upgrades involve complex operations and can fail. This section provides guidance for rolling back to a previous release of OpenStack. Although only tested on Ubuntu, other distributions follow a similar procedure.rollbacksprocess forupgradingrolling back failures" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1863(para) msgid "In this section, we consider only the most immediate case: you have taken down production management services in preparation for an upgrade, completed part of the upgrade process, discovered one or more problems not encountered during testing, and you must roll back your environment to the original \"known good\" state. Make sure that you did not make any state changes after attempting the upgrade process: no new instances, networks, storage volumes, and so on." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1872(para) msgid "Within this scope, you must complete these steps to successfully roll back your environment:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1877(para) msgid "Roll back configuration files." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1881(para) msgid "Roll back databases." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1885(para) msgid "Roll back packages." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1889(para) msgid "The upgrade instructions provided in earlier sections ensure that you have proper backups of your databases and configuration files. Read through this section carefully and verify that you have the requisite backups to restore. Rolling back upgrades is a tricky process because distributions tend to put much more effort into testing upgrades than downgrades. Broken downgrades often take significantly more effort to troubleshoot and, hopefully, resolve than broken upgrades. Only you can weigh the risks of trying to push a failed upgrade forward versus rolling it back. Generally, consider rolling back as the very last option." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1901(para) msgid "The following steps described for Ubuntu have worked on at least one production environment, but they might not work for all environments." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1906(title) msgid "To perform the rollback from Havana to Grizzly" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1909(para) msgid "Stop all OpenStack services." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1913(para) msgid "Copy contents of configuration backup directories /etc/<service>.grizzly that you created during the upgrade process back to /etc/<service>:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1920(para) msgid "Restore databases from the grizzly-db-backup.sql backup file that you created with the command during the upgrade process:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1927(para) msgid "If you created this backup by using the flag as instructed, you can proceed to the next step. If you omitted this flag, MySQL reverts all tables that existed in Grizzly, but does not drop any tables created during the database migration for Havana. In this case, you must manually determine which tables to drop, and drop them to prevent issues with your next upgrade attempt." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1939(para) msgid "Downgrade OpenStack packages." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1942(para) msgid "Downgrading packages is by far the most complicated step; it is highly dependent on the distribution and the overall administration of the system." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1949(para) msgid "Determine which OpenStack packages are installed on your system. Use the command. Filter for OpenStack packages, filter again to omit packages explicitly marked in the deinstall state, and save the final output to a file. For example, the following command covers a controller node with keystone, glance, nova, neutron, and cinder:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1997(para) msgid "Depending on the type of server, the contents and order of your package list might vary from this example." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:2004(para) msgid "You can determine the package versions available for reversion by using the command. If you removed the Grizzly repositories, you must first reinstall them and run :" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:2035(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:2087(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:2094(para) msgid "Use the command to install specific versions of each package by specifying <package-name>=<version>. The script in the previous step conveniently created a list of package=version pairs for you:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:2103(para) msgid "This step completes the rollback procedure. You should remove the Havana repository and run to prevent accidental upgrades until you solve whatever issue caused you to roll back your environment."
deleted_lines: "POT-Creation-Date: 2014-06-04 06:04+0000\n"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:10(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:152(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:19(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:21(para) msgid "Probably the most important step of all is the pre-upgrade testing. Especially if you are upgrading immediately after release of a new version, undiscovered bugs might hinder your progress. Some deployers prefer to wait until the first point release is announced. However, if you have a significant deployment, you might follow the development and testing of the release, thereby ensuring that bugs for your use cases are fixed.upgradingpre-upgrade testing"msgid "Each OpenStack cloud is different, and as a result, even with what may seem a near-identical architecture to this guide, you must still test upgrades between versions in your environment. For this, you need an approximate clone of your environment."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:38(para) msgid "However, that is not to say that it needs to be the same size or use identical hardware as the production environment—few of us have that luxury. It is important to consider the hardware and scale of the cloud you are upgrading, but here are some tips to avoid that incredible cost:upgradingcontrolling cost of"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:50(term)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:53(para) msgid "The simplest place to start testing the next version of OpenStack is by setting up a new environment inside your own cloud. This may seem odd—especially the double virtualization used in running compute nodes—but it's a sure way to very quickly test your configuration."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:62(term)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:65(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:79(term)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:82(para) msgid "If you use an external storage plug-in or shared file system with your cloud, in many cases, it's possible to test that it works by creating a second share or endpoint. This will enable you to test the system before entrusting the new version onto your storage."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:91(term)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:94(para) msgid "Even at smaller-scale testing, it should be possible to determine whether something is going horribly wrong in intercomponent communication if you look at the network packets and see too many."msgid "To actually set up the test environment, there are several methods. Some prefer to do a full manual install using the OpenStack Installation Guides and then see what the final configuration files look like and which packages were installed. Others prefer to create a clone of their automated configuration infrastructure with changed package repository URLs and then alter the configuration until it starts working. Either approach is valid, and which you use depends on experience."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:113(para) msgid "An upgrade pre-testing system is excellent for getting the configuration to work; however, it is important to note that the historical use of the system and differences in user interaction can affect the success of upgrades, too. We've seen experiences where database migrations encountered a bug (later fixed!) because of slight table differences between fresh Grizzly installs and those that migrated from Folsom to Grizzly."msgid "Artificial scale testing can go only so far. Once your cloud is upgraded, you'll also need to pay careful attention to the performance aspects of your cloud."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:127(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:129(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:154(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:158(para) msgid "Perform some \"cleaning\" of the environment prior to starting the upgrade process to ensure a consistent state. For example, instances not fully purged from the system after deletion may cause indeterminate behavior." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:165(para) msgid "Read the release notes and documentation." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:169(para) msgid "Find incompatibilities between your versions."msgid "Develop an upgrade procedure and assess it thoroughly using a test environment similar to your production environment."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:178(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:182(para) msgid "You can perform an upgrade with operational instances, but this strategy can be dangerous. You might consider using live migration to temporarily relocate instances to other compute nodes while performing upgrades. However, you must ensure database consistency throughout the process; otherwise your environment may become unstable. Also, don't forget to provide sufficient notice to your users, including giving them plenty of time to perform their own backups."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:190(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:195(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:199(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:203(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:208(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:212(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:216(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:220(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:224(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:229(para) msgid "Upgrade the packages using your distribution's package manager."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:234(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:239(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:245(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:249(para) msgid "For this section, we assume that you are starting with the architecture provided in the OpenStack Installation Guide and upgrading to the same architecture for Havana. All nodes should run Ubuntu 12.04 LTS. This section primarily addresses upgrading core OpenStack services, such as the Identity Service (keystone), Image Service (glance), Compute (nova) including networking, Block Storage (cinder), and the dashboard.upgradingGrizzly to Havana (Ubuntu)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:263(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:633(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:995(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:265(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:635(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:996(para) msgid "The upgrade process will interrupt management of your environment, including the dashboard. If you properly prepare for this upgrade, tenant instances will continue to operate normally."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:271(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:641(title) Particularly, if you are running Django 1.5 or later, you must ensure that /etc/openstack-dashboard/local_settings contains a correctly configured ALLOWED_HOSTS key that contains a list of hostnames recognized by the dashboard."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:425(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:818(para) msgid "If users will access your dashboard using http://dashboard.example.com, you would set:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:430(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:823(para) msgid "If users will access your dashboard on the local system, you would set:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:435(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:828(para) msgid "If users will access your dashboard using an IP address in addition to a hostname, you would set:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:442(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:835(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:444(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1079(para) msgid "Upgrade packages on the controller node to Havana, as shown below:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:451(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1084(para) msgid "Depending on your specific configuration, performing a dist-upgrade may restart services supplemental to your OpenStack environment. For example, if you use Open-iSCSI for Block Storage volumes and the upgrade includes a new open-scsi package, the package manager will restart Open-iSCSI services, which may cause the volumes for your users to be disconnected."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:459(para) msgid "The package manager will ask you about updating various configuration files. We recommend denying these changes. The package manager will append .dpkg-dist to the end of newer versions of existing configuration files. You should consider adopting conventions associated with the newer configuration files and merging them with your existing configuration files after completing the upgrade process."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:469(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:862(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:472(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:865(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:479(term) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:872(term)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:490(term) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:883(term)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:502(term) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:895(term)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:522(term) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:915(term)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:534(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:927(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:539(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:932(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:542(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:935(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:548(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:593(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:940(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:553(para) msgid "Due to a packaging issue, this command may fail with the following error:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:565(para) msgid "You can fix this issue by using the following command:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:570(para) msgid "The packaging system will ask about updating the /etc/nova/api-paste.ini file. As with the controller upgrade, we recommend denying these changes and reviewing the .dpkg-dist file after completing the upgrade process."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:576(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:584(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:956(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:587(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:959(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:597(para) msgid "The packaging system will ask about updating the /etc/cinder/api-paste.ini file. Like the controller upgrade, we recommend denying these changes and reviewing the .dpkg-dist file after completing the upgrade process."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:605(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:613(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:618(para) msgid "For this section, we assume that you are starting with the architecture provided in the OpenStack Installation Guide and upgrading to the same architecture for Havana. All nodes should run Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6.4 or compatible derivatives. Newer minor releases should also work. This section primarily addresses upgrading core OpenStack services, such as the Identity Service (keystone), Image Service (glance), Compute (nova) including networking, Block Storage (cinder), and the dashboard.upgradingGrizzly to Havana (Red Hat)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:653(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:667(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:688(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:729(para) msgid "If currently present, remove the following key from the [filter:authtoken] section in /etc/glance/glance-api-paste.ini and /etc/glance/glance-registry-paste.ini:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:740(para) msgid "Add the new [database] section and associated key to /etc/nova/nova.conf:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:746(para) msgid "Remove defunct database configuration from /etc/nova/nova.conf:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:765(para) msgid "On all compute nodes, increase the DHCP lease time (measured in seconds) in /etc/nova/nova.conf to enable currently active instances to continue leasing their IP addresses during the upgrade process, as shown here:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:781(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:787(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:790(para) msgid "Add the new [database] section and associated key to /etc/cinder/cinder.conf:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:796(para) msgid "Remove defunct database configuration from /etc/cinder/cinder.conf:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:842(para) msgid "Some services may terminate with an error during the package upgrade process. If this may cause a problem with your environment, consider stopping all services before upgrading them to Havana."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:847(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:853(para) msgid "The package manager will append .rpmnew to the end of newer versions of existing configuration files. You should consider adopting conventions associated with the newer configuration files and merging them with your existing configuration files after completing the upgrade process."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:944(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:948(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:964(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:969(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:973(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:979(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:981(para) msgid "For this section, we assume that you are starting with the architecture provided in the OpenStack Installation Guide and upgrading to the same architecture for Icehouse. All nodes should run Ubuntu 12.04 LTS with Linux kernel 3.11 and the latest Havana packages installed and operational. This section primarily addresses upgrading core OpenStack services such as Identity (keystone), Image Service (glance), Compute (nova), Networking (neutron), Block Storage (cinder), and the dashboard. The Networking upgrade includes conversion from the Open vSwitch (OVS) plug-in to the Modular Layer 2 (M2) plug-in. This section does not cover the upgrade process from Ubuntu 12.04 LTS to Ubuntu 14.04 LTS."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1003(para) msgid "Always review the release notes before performing an upgrade to learn about newly available features that you may want to enable and deprecated features that you should disable."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1025(para) msgid "Although not necessary, you should consider updating your MySQL server configuration as described in the MySQL controller setup section of the Installation Guide."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1035(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1040(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1044(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1047(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1048(para) msgid "Icehouse disables file injection by default per the release notes."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1051(para) msgid "If you plan to deploy Icehouse in stages, you must disable file injection on all compute nodes that will remain on Havana."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1054(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1062(para) msgid "Convert from OVS to ML2 plug-in:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1063(para) msgid "You must convert the configuration for your environment contained in the /etc/neutron/neutron.conf and /etc/neutron/plugins/openvswitch/ovs_neutron_plugin.ini files from OVS to ML2. One way to quickly find what configuration files are yet to be merged is using the following command:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1104(title) msgid "Upgrade Each Service" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1105(para) msgid "The upgrade procedure for each service typically requires that you stop the service, run the database synchronization command to update the associated database, and start the service to apply the new configuration. ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1329(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1333(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1334(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1349(para) msgid "On all distributions, you need to perform some final tasks to complete the upgrade process.upgradingfinal steps"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1356(para) msgid "Decrease DHCP timeouts by modifying /etc/nova/nova.conf on the compute nodes back to the original value for your environment."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1360(para) msgid "Update all of the .ini files to match passwords and pipelines as required for Havana in your environment."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1363(para) msgid "After a migration, your users will see different results from nova image-list and glance image-list unless you match up policies for access to private images. To do so, edit /etc/glance/policy.json and /etc/nova/policy.json to contain \"context_is_admin\": \"role:admin\", which limits access to private images for projects."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1372(para) msgid "Thoroughly test the environment, and then let your users know that their cloud is running normally again."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1377(title) msgid "Rolling Back a Failed Upgrade"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1379(para) msgid "While we do not wish this fate upon anyone, upgrades involve complex operations and can fail. This section provides guidance for rolling back to a previous release of OpenStack. Although only tested on Ubuntu, other distributions follow a similar procedure.rollbacksprocess forupgradingrolling back failures"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1393(para) msgid "In this section, we consider only the most immediate case: you have taken down production management services in preparation for an upgrade, completed part of the upgrade process, discovered one or more problems not encountered during testing, and need to roll back your environment to the original \"known good\" state. We specifically assume that you did not make any state changes after attempting the upgrade process: no new instances, networks, storage volumes, etc." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1401(para) msgid "Within this scope, you need to accomplish three main steps to successfully roll back your environment:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1406(para) msgid "Roll back configuration files" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1410(para) msgid "Roll back databases" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1414(para) msgid "Roll back packages" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1418(para) msgid "The upgrade instructions provided in earlier sections ensure that you have proper backups of your databases and configuration files. You should read through this section carefully and verify that you have the requisite backups to restore. Rolling back upgrades is a tricky process because distributions tend to put much more effort into testing upgrades than downgrades. Broken downgrades often take significantly more effort to troubleshoot and, hopefully, resolve than broken upgrades. Only you can weigh the risks of trying to push a failed upgrade forward versus rolling it back. Generally, we consider rolling back the very last option." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1428(para) msgid "The following steps described for Ubuntu have worked on at least one production environment, but they may not work for all environments." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1432(title) msgid "Perform the rollback from Havana to Grizzly" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1435(para) msgid "Stop all OpenStack services." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1439(para) msgid "Copy contents of configuration backup directories /etc/<service>.grizzly that you created during the upgrade process back to /etc/<service>:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1446(para) msgid "Restore databases from the backup file grizzly-db-backup.sql that you created with mysqldump during the upgrade process:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1452(para) msgid "If you created this backup using the --add-drop-database flag as instructed, you can proceed to the next step. If you omitted this flag, MySQL will revert all of the tables that existed in Grizzly, but not drop any tables created during the database migration for Havana. In this case, you need to manually determine which tables should not exist and drop them to prevent issues with your next upgrade attempt." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1463(para) msgid "Downgrade OpenStack packages." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1466(para) msgid "We consider downgrading packages by far the most complicated step; it is highly dependent on the distribution as well as overall administration of the system." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1473(para) msgid "Determine the OpenStack packages installed on your system. This is done using dpkg --get-selections, filtering for OpenStack packages, filtering again to omit packages explicitly marked in the deinstall state, and saving the final output to a file. For example, the following command covers a controller node with keystone, glance, nova, neutron, and cinder:"msgid "Depending on the type of server, the contents and order of your package list may vary from this example."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1526(para) msgid "You can determine the package versions available for reversion by using apt-cache policy. If you removed the Grizzly repositories, you must first reinstall them and run apt-get update:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1557(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1608(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1615(para) msgid "Use apt-get install to install specific versions of each package by specifying <package-name>=<version>. The script in the previous step conveniently created a list of package=version pairs for you:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml:1623(para) msgid "This completes the rollback procedure. You should remove the Havana repository and run apt-get update to prevent accidental upgrades until you solve whatever issue caused you to roll back your environment."

commit_message:
Make exception handling in get_image_metadata more specific

The generic try/except with Exception was masking an
AttributeError raised during migration flows in conductor.

This change makes the error handling specific to the translated
exceptions raised from the image service in nova.image.glance,
specifically the _translate_image_exception method.

Related-Bug: #1326926

Change-Id: I3e4db73569fc1b02d7a05b4ab10fe83fec956922

commit_message:
live migrate conductor tasks to use nova.image.API

While the patch (I67e7c9d841e5bad82cdca8f7048eaa57f0cfbb2f) was being
reviewed, live_migrate functionality was moved to the conductor. This
live_migrate task code needed to be updated to refer to the new
nova.image.API object instead of the old nova.glance.GlanceImageService
object, which had a slightly different API.

Change-Id: I7ddb778432643f4b5371d11b675951fc678135c5
Closes-bug: #1326926

commit_message:
Allowing for HDFS data sources without hdfs://

Now that HDFS data sources can be either full URLs
or paths relative to the cluster itself, it is no
longer desirable to force "hdfs://" at the start
of hdfs data sources.
* No longer force the prefix on the create form
* For swift, we now check to see that the location
  starts with swift://, if it doesn't we add it

Change-Id: Id1fcdb741ce702ad194cf86556be2f3f0e8cd049
Partial-Bug:  bug 1315126

commit_message:
Add log translation hints for lvm and rbd

Oslo would like to see hints like this in all of our code
by the end of juno. We should slowly trickle the changes
out over the release.
This patch only cover lvm driver and ceph rbd driver.

Relate info about log translation hints as follows:
    https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo/+spec/log-messages-translation-domain-rollout
    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/70455

Change-Id: Ib7b66d14b47deb0a3f2d8f27a6cd599befdc4d6c
Closes-Bug: #1328397

commit_message:
enables patch ports when availble for connecting openvswitch bridges

The current implementation for connecting openvswtich bridges
when when not using vxlan or gre tunnels is via veth pairs.

This patch enables the use of openvswitch patch-ports for local, flat and
vlan deployments with a fall back to veth pairs in the eventuality
patch-ports are not supported.

Implements blueprint openvswitch-patch-port-use

Change-Id: I70376c74e18c718f48c9d4caadaaf80c0095fc74

commit_message:
Fix misnamed baremetal state DELETED

* The baremetal state "DELETED" actually indicates that node is powered
  off, hence introducing a appropriate state "POWER_OFF" to indicate the
  same, instead of "DELETED" which is confusing.

Change-Id: I396425f7c127366b0fa66125ba5a96c3b7f633f9
Closes-Bug: #1185081

commit_message:
Fixes v2 return status on unauthorized download

If a user is not allowed to download an image because of a policy,
glance v2 API responds with a  HTTP 200 status and no data instead
of HTTP 403 for no cache only.
The problem is that get_data implementation for notification
proxy is a generator, this situation delays the other proxies
get_data calls (including the policy proxy) for the first time
data is retrieved.
Hence, there is a delay in enforcing policy, so 200 is sent before
the API gets the chance to catch the policy exception.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1326781
Change-Id: I1e50a069a6b7f9eed7160cd5908a5fa30274e227

commit_message:
Corrects proxy server conf in swift install guide

The install and configuration guide for object storage has
proxy-server.conf contents with /home/swift/keystone-signing as
signing directory. Without the directory being available swift proxy
service is unable to start. Signing directory is a temporary cache
directory which defaults to /tmp. Hence removing this entry makes
/tmp as default signing directory. This patch removes signing_dir
option to make swift use /tmp as signing directory implicitly.

Change-Id: I8b9b70b30af2767f48705acb14329833179b96fc
Closes-Bug: #1329798
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/57/100057/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>Create swift home directory:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>mkdir -p /home/swift</userinput></screen> </step> <step> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>chown -R swift:swift /home/swift</userinput></screen>

commit_message:
Support Keystone V3 API

Keystone API v2 is deprecated in Icehouse.
All projects client need to switch to v3 API
at end of Juno. We should add v3 support in
python-cinderclient.

blueprint support-keystone-v3-api

Change-Id: I3e2b10643d67d96fa78a590bf0534bda6dba4279
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/11/97711/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================== Support Keystone V3 API ======================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/python-cinderclient/+spec/support-keystone-v3-api Keystone API v2 is deprecated in Icehouse. All projects client need to switch to v3 API at end of Juno. We should add v3 support in python-cinderclient. Problem description =================== Now the cinder client only support Keystone V2 API, but Keystone V2 API is deprecated in Icehouse, so We need to switch to Keystone V3 API in cinder client and the support additional authentication domain specific parameters. Proposed change =============== Based on os-auth-url to decide keystone api version. If os-auth-url look like this 'http://localhost:5000/v3', authenticate with keystone v3 api. By default user and project belong to default domain, so 'default' is the default value of user-domain and project-domain. os-tenant-id and os-tenant-name are deprecated, replaced with os-project-id and os-project-name, aims to unifying parameters about tenant/project, but the old tenant parameters can be used as normal and is backwards compatibility enabled. Adding new parameters about user/project domain specific, like as: os-project-domain-id, os-project-domain-name, os-user-domain-id, os-user-domain-name, in shell.py the new options are added to the parser. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- In order to authenticate with V3 in keystone, if a username is provided for authentication, the user's domain name or id must also be provided. Similarly, if a tenant/project name is provided, the project's domain name or id must also be specified. The tenant parameters is deprecated like as os-tenant-id and os-tenant-name, They are replaced with os-project-id and os-project-name, but the tenant parameters is backwards compatibility and can be used, just don't show in 'cinder help'. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Same as the end user impact. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <kiwik-chenrui> Work Items ---------- * Deprecate old tenant parameters: os-tenant-id and os-tenant-name. But tenant parameters is backwards compatibility. * Add new project parameters: os-project-id and os-project-id. * Add new domain specific parameters: os-project-domain-id, os-project-domain-name, os-user-domain-id, os-user-domain-name. * Add logic in OpenStackCinderShell to get new project parameters and domain parameters, keep tenant parameters be backwards compatibility. * Modify the init method of cinder v1/v2 Client and HTTPClient, pass the domain parameters. * Modify the authenticate method in HTTPClient, add logic about supporting Keystone V3 API. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Add new unit testing code to test v3 code. Documentation Impact ==================== The new domain specific parameters for the cinder command should be documented. os-tenant-id and os-tenant-name are deprecated, replace them with os-project-id and os-project-name, but backwards compatibility is enabled. * Deprecated parameters: * os-tenant-id * os-tenant-name * New parameters: * os-project-id * os-project-name * os-project-domain-id * os-project-domain-name * os-user-domain-id * os-user-domain-name References ========== None

commit_message:
Update websocketproxy to work with websockify 0.6

Websockify version 0.6 bring with it several bugfixes
and new features that affect Nova (including a fix for
novncproxy zombies hanging around and better support
for the python logging framework).  However, it also
broke backwards compatibility due to a refactor which
brought it inline with other Python socket server libraries.

This patch updates the websockify code to function with
websockify version 0.6 as well as websockify version 0.5.x.

Change-Id: I7858dbb49bee8de3fe725beb6793eac3ecba71b6

commit_message:
Added more correct check of refs in test_vm_util

Method get_all_cluster_refs_by_name() returns
a dictionary and we want to know that this
dictionary is empty. It's not quite right
to convert dictionary to bollean and check
that it's False. It would be better if we
check the length of this dictionary.

Change-Id: Ib41cf96efa209412e723e3f43ca3d6dd89fea400

commit_message:
virt: Let six.moves.urllib to handle urllib/urllib2

Though nova hasn't the road map of Python 3 compatibility, it's not a
good practice of using six.moves.urllib with urllib/urllib2 together.
This commit unifies the urllib related usage in virt directory.
For usage of six.moves.urllib, please refer to
https://pythonhosted.org/six/#module-six.moves.urllib.parse

Change-Id: Ifc568b964a6ec815139b433c0089ed41c7e7abf5

commit_message:
move python_packages attributes from dependent cookbooks

Move the database client python packages attributes from dependent
cookbooks in -common so we don't duplicate them everywhere.

Change-Id: If45621d31889a582dde62474c4b08f52905a277f
Implements: blueprint move-python-db-client-attrs-to-common

added_lines: # platform and DBMS-specific python client packages case node['platform_family'] when 'rhel' default['openstack']['db']['python_packages'] = { mysql: ['MySQL-python'], db2: ['python-ibm-db', 'python-ibm-db-sa'], postgresql: ['python-psycopg2'] } when 'suse' default['openstack']['db']['python_packages'] = { mysql: ['python-mysql'], postgresql: ['python-psycopg2'] } when 'debian' default['openstack']['db']['python_packages'] = { mysql: ['python-mysqldb'], postgresql: ['python-psycopg2'] } end

commit_message:
move developer_mode tests into their own block

This should make it clearer that the developer_mode is a special
case. It will also make it easier to remove if we decide to abandon
developer_mode in the future.

Change-Id: I989971c193b73481fea45853e94f0442e476374b

commit_message: Add instanceset info to StartInstance response Currently startinstance response doesn't have the instanceset information with InstanceID, current state and previous state. It just returns the "True". As per the AWS API reference document, the StartInstance response elements should include the instanceset information as below: req-a7326465-5ce2-4ed6-ab89-394b38cca85f i-00000001 16 running 80 stopped Included the instanceset in to startinstance response elements and updated the test cases for startinstance response elements in nova/tests/api/ec2/test_cloud.py file. Change-Id: I046a7b931f41afde0db52ba27dcf4564729d32ae Closes-bug: #1321220
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/47/100847/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _format_start_instances(self, context, instance_id, previous_states): instances_set = [] for (ec2_id, previous_state) in zip(instance_id, previous_states): i = {} i['instanceId'] = ec2_id i['previousState'] = _state_description(previous_state['vm_state'], previous_state['shutdown_terminate']) i['currentState'] = _state_description(vm_states.ACTIVE, True) instances_set.append(i) return {'instancesSet': instances_set} return self._format_start_instances(context, instance_id, instances)

commit_message:
Remove check_doc.py and use doc8

Instead of using a helper script that is internal to taskflow
use the doc8 package (which was created based on the check_doc.py
work) instead. This avoids repeating duplicated code when an
external pypi package can provide the same functionality.

Change-Id: I32d430f5b1ff9d291c38cc50342c2c973ebdd27d

subject: Destroy instance to clear node state on failure
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-12 00:33:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/74aeb8fa20cf1fb177705eca35e86a92b1b02c27', 'message': 'Destroy instance to clear node state on failure

After a node has failed to deploy an instance, ensure the instance is
destroyed from the virt driver.  This clears the node state entirely before

After a node has failed to deploy an instance, ensure the instance is
destroyed from the virt driver.  This clears the node state entirely before
the instance gets rescheduled.

commit_message:
Destroy instance to clear node state on failure

After a node has failed to deploy an instance, ensure the instance is
destroyed from the virt driver.  This clears the node state entirely before
the instance gets rescheduled.

Change-Id: I6a5d04f4c26c0910274783c0f686b0542af15f9c
Closes-bug: #1326364.

commit_message:
Clean nova.compute.api.API:_check_num_instances_quota

Simplification to a better understanding of total_allowed value
Originally:
total_allowed = used + headroom [resource]
with used = quotas [resource] - headroom [resource]
So total_allowed = quotas [resource]

Change-Id: Ie4b1f6cb8f0fd80610bdf3fb10ea0263281f56c0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/44/100544/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: total_allowed = quotas[resource]

commit_message:
properly quote www-authenticate header value

HTTP header values should be quoted. Since the WWW-Authenticate
header value contains user-supplied strings, it's important to
ensure it's properly quoted to ensure the integrity of the protocol.

Previous to this patch, the URL was unquoted and then the unquoted
value was returned in the header. This patch re-quotes the value
when it is set on the response.

This is filed as CVS-2014-3497

Fixes bug 1327414

Change-Id: If8bd8842f2ce821756e9b4461a18a8ac8d42fb8c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/32/101032/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

' # url injection test quoted_hacker = quote(hacker) req = swift.common.swob.Request.blank('/v1/' + hacker) resp = req.get_response(test_app) self.assertEquals(resp.status_int, 401) self.assert_('Www-Authenticate' in resp.headers) self.assertEquals('Swift realm="%s"' % quoted_hacker, resp.headers['Www-Authenticate']) req = swift.common.swob.Request.blank('/v1/' + quoted_hacker) resp = req.get_response(test_app) self.assertEquals(resp.status_int, 401) self.assert_('Www-Authenticate' in resp.headers) self.assertEquals('Swift realm="%s"' % quoted_hacker, resp.headers['Www-Authenticate'])

Change-Id: I6f5c509407d8523735a99aee88e6df4e425e85c0
'}]
commit_message:
Support of host-routes and dns_nameservers via DHCP options for the Nuage Plugin

Change-Id: I6f5c509407d8523735a99aee88e6df4e425e85c0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/41/101041/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: =========================================================================== Adding support for host-routes and dns_nameservers options for Nuage Plugin =========================================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/dhcp-host-routes-and-dns-support-for-nuage-plugin.rst Adding support for host-routes and dns_nameservers options via DHCP options for the Nuage Plugin Problem description =================== The current the Nuage Plugin does not support adding host routes or DNS nameservers via DHCP options for a Neutron subnet. Proposed change =============== Currently the Nuage Plugin does not support Neutron's adding host routes or DNS nameservers via DHCP options on a subnet. The Nuage's VSP supports this feature and the support needs to be added in the plugin code. The following DHCP options will be supported : - DNS nameserver - Host routes The proposed change is to support the creation of DNS nameserver and/or Host routes using the Neutron DNS and Host routes For example: neutron subnet-create test 192.168.10.0/24 --dns_nameservers list=true 8.8.4.4 8.8.8.8 This action will create a subnet name test with a CIDR 192.168.10.0/24. The nameservers _8.8.4.4 8.8.8.8_ will added to this subnet, this translate to a subnet in the Nuage's VSP subnet with the same nameservers The CRUD operations will be supported by the Nuage's VSP plugin for both DNS nameserver and Host routes. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== The modification are required on the plugin.py * The new method __create_port_gateway will be created. This method will create a port of type network:dhcp for the current subnet and tenant ```python def _create_port_gateway(self, context, subnet): port_dict = dict(port=dict( name='', device_id='', admin_state_up=True, network_id=subnet['network_id'], tenant_id=subnet['tenant_id'], fixed_ips=[{'subnet_id': subnet['id']}], mac_address=attributes.ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED, device_owner=os_constants.DEVICE_OWNER_DHCP)) port = super(NuagePlugin, self).create_port(context, port_dict) return port['fixed_ips'][0]['ip_address'] ``` * The __validate_create_subnet method will be modified to allow the host_routes key to be a valid options of the subnet dictionary _(the comment denotes what will be removed)_ ```python def _validate_create_subnet(self, subnet): # if ('host_routes' in subnet and # attributes.is_attr_set(subnet['host_routes'])): # msg = 'host_routes extensions not supported for subnets' # raise nuage_exc.OperationNotSupported(msg=msg) if subnet['gateway_ip'] is None: msg = "no-gateway option not supported with subnets" raise nuage_exc.OperationNotSupported(msg=msg) ``` * The update_subnet method will be added to the plugin ```python def update_subnet(self, context, id, subnet): subn = copy.deepcopy(subnet['subnet']) subnet_l2dom = nuagedb.get_subnet_l2dom_by_id(context.session, id) params = { 'parent_id': subnet_l2dom['nuage_subnet_id'], 'type': subnet_l2dom['nuage_l2dom_tmplt_id'] } with context.session.begin(subtransactions=True): neutron_subnet = super(NuagePlugin, self).update_subnet(context, id, subnet) self.nuageclient.update_subnet(subn, params) return neutron_subnet ``` * The _create_nuage_subnet method will be merged into the create_subnet method. This will newly updated method will also create a DHCP port using the method _create_port_gateway described above. (the method has been reduced for better readability)_ ```python def create_subnet(self, context, subnet): self._validate_create_subnet(subn) net_partition = self._get_net_partition_for_subnet(context, subnet) neutron_subnet = super(NuagePlugin, self).create_subnet(context, subnet) # TODO Create a dhcp port and get the ip for it ip = self._create_port_gateway(context, neutron_subnet) net = netaddr.IPNetwork(neutron_subnet['cidr']) params = { 'net_partition': net_partition, 'tenant_id': neutron_subnet['tenant_id'], 'net': net, 'dhcp_ip': ip } try: nuage_subnet = self.nuageclient.create_subnet(neutron_subnet, params) ``` Assignee(s) ----------- Franck Yelles Primary assignee: fyelles Other contributors: Work Items ---------- * Extension code in Nuage plugin * Nuage CI coverage addition * Nuage Unit tests additions, the following test units will be updated/added : * test_create_subnet_bad_hostroutes * test_update_subnet_adding_additional_host_routes_and_dns * test_create_subnet_with_one_host_route * test_create_subnet_with_two_host_routes * test_create_subnet_with_too_many_routes * test_update_subnet_route * test_update_subnet_route_to_None * test_update_subnet_route_with_too_many_entries * test_delete_subnet_with_route * test_delete_subnet_with_dns_and_route * test_validate_subnet_host_routes_exhausted * test_validate_subnet_dns_nameservers_exhausted Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit Test coverage for the DHCP options within Nuage unit test Nuage CI will be modified to start supporting this extension tests Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
Fix the duplicated image params in a test

In _test_create, there is a parameter "no_image" to disable "image_ref"
in a request body of "create a server" API. The way of disabling is
setting '' as "image_ref".
So the unit tests using _test_create pass the duplicated images:
the parameter image_ref '' and the parameter block_device_mapping

This patch fixes this duplicated image parameters.
This problem was detected through the API validation works and
Ic17d2227909c9180ca86c9d578dad4c73ec57dfc needs this fixing.

Change-Id: I36ffc87309afadec7da3fa19e01ea8f00f0f9f8d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/85/100785/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: del body['server']['image_ref']

commit_message:
Add task/flow listener support around the volume api flow

This will add in logging of what is occurring around the
actions taken by taskflow when taskflow executes the initial
create_volume workflow.

Since the oslo logging module will include the request_id of
the currently active request (per greenthread) this will make
it easier to understand and debug the actions occurring inside
taskflow's engine concept.

Part of blueprint task-logging

Change-Id: I57a6f85ecac37fc4f97033eb3b7a0dc8bd35a886
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/83/99783/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinder.volume.flows import common as flow_common # Attaching this listener will capture all of the notifications that # taskflow sends out and redirect them to a more useful log for # cinders debugging (or error reporting) usage. with flow_common.DynamicLogListener(flow_engine): flow_engine.run() return flow_engine.storage.fetch('volume')

subject: Fix log capturing fixture
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-10 02:23:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/5d3b585e82a98fd68589d53e42f87a79a5ba46ec', 'message': 'Fix log capturing fixture

Instead of nuking the unit test logs capture them according
to how tempest (and oslotest) capture them so that the tests
when ran locally provide the full logging output instead of
a minaturized version.

This adds in the following environment variables which can
be used to control testr captured logging:

- OS_LOG_CAPTURE (turns on log capturing so that the testr
  repository will have log output, at a INFO level)
- OS_DEBUG (changes the captured logging level from INFO
  to DEBUG, only useful when OS_LOG_CAPTURE is enabled)

Change-Id: I63d9a1b7fc6e7591fd6309cf68d9269117c023a6
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-06-10 02:25:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/9b8bb6c653382fc9c54a55a2d5bec439d88296ab', 'message': 'Fix log capturing fixture

Instead of nuking the unit test logs capture them according
to how tempest (and oslotest) capture them so that the tests
when ran locally provide the full logging output instead of
a miniaturized version.

This adds in the following environment variables which can
be used to control testr captured logging:

- OS_LOG_CAPTURE (turns on log capturing so that the testr
  repository will have log output, at a INFO level)
- OS_DEBUG (changes the captured logging level from INFO
  to DEBUG, only useful when OS_LOG_CAPTURE is enabled)

Change-Id: I63d9a1b7fc6e7591fd6309cf68d9269117c023a6
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-06-10 22:25:30.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/test.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/090d57e9ce4c74c1a106a0bc7b583e566624f85d', 'message': 'Fix log capturing fixture

Instead of nuking the unit test logs capture them according
to how tempest (and oslotest) capture them so that the tests
when ran locally provide the full logging output instead of
a miniaturized version.

This adds in the following environment variables which can
be used to control testr captured logging:

- OS_LOG_CAPTURE (turns on log capturing so that the testr
  repository will have log output, at a INFO level)
- OS_DEBUG (changes the captured logging level from INFO
  to DEBUG, only useful when OS_LOG_CAPTURE is enabled)

It also creates a lambda that is used to test whether an
environment is enabled (avoiding recreating the same set
of checks in multiple places).

Change-Id: I63d9a1b7fc6e7591fd6309cf68d9269117c023a6
